headline: Trump demands bipartisan effort to tackle border security
subHeadline: President Trump warns of potential government shutdown if Congress fails to act on border security, funding the wall; reaction and analysis on 'The Five.'

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello, everyone. I'm Dana Perino along with Jedediah Bila, Doug Schoen, Lawrence Jones, and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is "The Five." We certainly hope you all had a happy Thanksgiving with a lot of delicious feasting with family and friends. Before we get to the rest of the show, let's go around the table. See how everyone's Thanksgiving was. I think we have to start with you, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: It was great. The producers asked us if we would supply pictures.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So I did. So, this is the turkey. And then, that's a bowl of stuffing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: The stuffing was great. I -- like Lawrence, I went off on my Atkins diet and had some stuffing. There was green beans, which was delicious. And we have some corn on the cob. I was at a restaurant.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: They serve corn on the cob on Thanksgiving?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, it looks like sliced. I was at a restaurant and I think I have a picture of me and the people I was with. You could see there's Sean, there's Laura, Tucker, and me. We're just enjoying a nice meal. This is what we do outside of work.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That looks very fun. That looks very fun. Lawrence, you're in Dallas?

utterances.speaker: LAWRENCE JONES, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Yes. So, I cook a lot of these stuffs. My mom had lupus growing up and so she taught me how to cook very early, so I cook. A lot of my family got together and talk politics, actually. It didn't play that way because my mom already said none of that. Here's a pecan pie. But it was very civil. It's a civil conversation. Nobody was screaming at each other. I mean, we naturally talk loud, but it went well.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: We've showed pictures of ourselves. You're showing picture of the food that you made. Doug, what you do?

utterances.speaker: DOUG SCHOEN, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: You know, my mother is 92. She is sharp as a tack. And she and I and a friend went out to a hotel, and my mother had whatever she wanted with the active support and love of her son. It was the right kind of Thanksgiving. Thanks for asking.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: She earned that.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: She did. And I felt proud.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And we're thankful. This is your first time on The Five.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: Yeah. And my mother is -- I hope watching, but thank you, mom, for everything. And thank you for all the love and support that you've given me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Does she still have a cocktail or --

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: She has a cocktail whatever she wants with my support and love. She's earned it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's exactly --

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: She's sharper than I am.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Exactly, I agree.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: What's her cocktail of choice?

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: Her cocktail of choice is prosecco. The only thing she says to me is how do you as a centrist turned out as you did, because she's far left and --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. Jedediah, how was your Thanksgiving?

utterances.speaker: JEDEDIAH BILA, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Yeah. It was good. We cooked. It was the first time that we cooked. My husband --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Turkey, no turkey?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: There's my husband with the turkey. He actually -- for his first turkey, it was delicious. I don't know what he did to it because I wasn't part of the part. But my dog was there. She had so much food. She had turkey, sweet potato, apple sauce. That's my angel. And I made a gluten- free stuffing that I was terrified it was going to be awful that was actually delicious.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Do you do that because you have issues with gluten or --

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Oh, here we go. Here we go. Be too trendy for you, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It is gluten-free.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: How about Dana? What did you do?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I took a bunch of pictures of my dog. I think we have those.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Of course.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He was out there.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: How is this any different?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: This is the table. We were down in Baha, New Jersey. And we -- my mom and her friend Barb are here in town, and Peter and I, we all went to the yacht club and then we joined on with the Landers family. They have a big family. And we have a small little family, so we got to be a part of them. So that was really fun. Pictures of my dog, that's the only thing I want --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: There is no C -- the C is silent in yacht.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. Isn't that interesting?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: We learn something new from you every day, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes. If you watched our Facebook live you too could have that from the four.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And you can win these pictures.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Win a picture?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, you can win these pictures. Guess what I'm thinking of right now?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: It's time to get back on the diet now. Yesterday was a cheat day.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: I'm jealous of you, Lawrence.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: Fifty-one pounds --

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: I'm jealous.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So you could buy a bunch of new clothes?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yeah, I'm doing it. Black Friday shopping.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. Well, we have a lot to get to, even though I would like to talk about Thanksgiving, but we have to move on to the border battle that's heating up. President Trump threatening to shut down the entire border if Mexico doesn't control the migrant caravan headed our way.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: I think we Democrats would benefit from a compromise.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: Do border security, do the wall, do DACA, and try to get a pathway to citizenship because these issues hurt the Democrats and it's clear it would help the Republicans too, because, look, Trump made the whole campaign about immigration, about the caravan. It didn't do so well in the congressional elections. And for him to broaden his appeal for 2020, a deal would help him. My advice in the lame duck session, start the process of getting it done. Tie it to criminal justice reform would be even better.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, that's going to be tough to get immigration done at the lame duck?

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: Yeah. But we've got to try because, ultimately, it will be tougher for the Republicans after the new congress is sworn in with Nancy Pelosi.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's true. I'm an optimist. I feel like something could get done, Jedediah, but these guys are telling me it could be tough.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: He ran -- I mean, this was the chief issue that President Trump ran on. And one of the reasons he got elected was immigration. That people felt he was going to be tough on it. He talked about the wall sensibly. So I think if there's an issue for him to really hit home on and really -- look, if you got to shut the government down, I know people on the left and some people on the right freak out when he's talking about a government shutdown --

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: It gets to the left --

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Yeah. But not necessarily because -- no, you know why it get to the left because they market it well, because they don't talk about the fact that so many essential government services actually continue when you have a government shutdown.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I feel like the tide is turning on it, though, Greg. Like you see the pictures every day, we talk about this issue every single day for years, and it feels like, to me, like it's coming to a head and might get it to a good place.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm a little pessimistic as well. It's obvious that for Donald Trump, this is a central concern of his that has long term benefits in his head, but has a short-term cost. You don't get good P.R., the media hates you. You're painted as a bigot. There're all this short term consequences to a long term benefit which is that your -- the changes in immigration is not being kept up with the current system. We update our phone every year. We have a system that we refuse to update for fear of being yelled at. So -- immigration highlights the differences between the constrained and unconstrained. Conservatives are constrained. They believe humans are fallible and will gain the system. So you need to have a process. But the left, unconstrained, believe in moral progress, and that laws are just temporary. And so --

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: The answer is not moral progress. It's political benefit. If Trump is flexible on what the wall is, and the Democrats are flexible on terms for DACA and a pathway to citizenship, the big winner will be Donald Trump because he'll be able to speak --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: But that's not what your base is. Your base -- the progressive wing of the party --

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: I'm not a progressive in case you haven't noticed.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: But I'm telling you, your party -- that's not what the energy of your party is right now --

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: Sadly, you're right.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: A lot of those people are open border progressive --

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: They are, and that's very bad.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: You have to please those people --

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: No, you don't have to please --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: But your leadership is, though, because she's fighting for reelection right now --

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: She's reelected, that's done.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: She doesn't have the full support of her caucus right now --

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: She does now.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: We don't need to shut them up. We just need to get the Republicans to do a deal that will benefit Trump, benefit the Democrats, and benefit the country.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: You know how this works, though, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I do.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: You're right, Jedediah. It's got to be border security first. I agree.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Here's the thing, I'm going to make one last point and then we'll go. It is that -- if both sides benefit from it politically from it being an issue, why can't the same be true that both sides would be benefit from it getting solved?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Because you're leaving out one central piece and that is the media which benefits from playing Santa. And it goes back to the short- term consequences, which is they could call Trump a racist. You can call conservatives bigots, and you can ignore the long-term benefits which is that this will make the country safer and better to have an immigration system that matches the current challenges. It's hard to be the adult.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's what we're dealing with right now, talking about walls and talking about immigration. That's the adult filter. The media has the child filter, which is, like, this is just mean. That's the challenge.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But if the Democrats say, we want to do a deal, then do you think the media will say, OK, will they support them in trying to get that done?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think they will do that if they actually get the White House, and then all of a sudden they become adults. Right now they don't have to.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But they try that in 2008, and Obama --

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: They should try it again now. It will help the Democrats.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. We could talk about this like -- Lawrence's Thanksgiving table.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Next, a subpoena showdown as Republican lawmakers ordered James Comey and Loretta Lynch to testify. Will they show up to answer questions? That's ahead.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: Before Democrats take control in January, house Republicans are slapping fired FBI director James Comey and former attorney general Loretta Lynch with subpoenas, calling on them to testify over the 2016 election and Clinton email probe. But getting their depositions may not be that easy. Comey vows to resist sitting down behind closed doors, saying that he will only answer questions in a public hearing. Congressman Trey Gowdy explains why GOP lawmakers don't want that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: I worked for Bill Clinton.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry to hear that.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: Increasingly having watched the ANE documentary about the Lewinsky scandal, I tend to share your views, sadly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Did you learn something new?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: -- is the fact that the Hillary Clinton email scandals has never fully been investigated. We don't know where those 31,000 emails went. We don't know about the classified emails that may have gone to the wrong people. We don't know why Loretta Lynch said it was a matter rather than an investigation. We do not know why Jim Comey did what I think, Greg, was just wrong on July of 2016, and wrong 10-11 days before the election. What say you? How do you see it?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I just don't want another episode of Mr. Smith goes to Washington. There should be a drinking game where every time he says my word, or aw, shucks, or good heavens, you've got to drink. I don't think I can take another round of -- moralizing. I actually hired a hypnotist to hypnotize our producers. They don't know this. They can't hear this right now. But every time someone says we need to put Comey on the show, they will actually hear more cat videos, amatory on the phrase guess what and robot stories.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: Dana --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Trust me.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: How did you feel when you read about the subpoenas being issued? Is it too much or appropriate?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think -- it possibly is futile, right? I don't think it's actually going to happen. I think is a last ditch effort by Republicans before they lose the chairmanship to try to get them to come in. And Comey always has a way to make this some sort of a P.R. thing. And, look, so if you're just not paying attention to this day-to-day and you see that Comey says, I'll come and testify, I just want it to be open so there's no leaking. I mean, that's actually a pretty decent message for him.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: Even though he did leak himself.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The leaking thing would be an interesting thing to ask him about.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: He refuses to admit it, though.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yeah. But I don't see an investigation that actually happens. I think the proper channel would have been if the president had a strong attorney general to actually look at their own departments and identify what's actually going on. The problem with James Comey, he's such a show man. I really don't like him. He reminds me of the conservative intellectuals out there that say they're the only ones that are conservative, or I am -- I'm so perfect. I think a lot of American people are turned off by him, especially because there are so many inconsistencies, investigates Hillary Clinton about a private email server, he has a private email, he investigates leaking, he leaks. I mean, he's so dishonest about himself. And I think at the end of the day, he's going to be known as the worst FBI director in American history.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: I certainly agree. He hasn't done himself any good in his public phase. I'm a sports fan, so I watch basketball and football. And I was thinking of Dean Smith, and North Carolina, and the four corners. I think, Jedediah, he --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's exactly what we were thinking.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'm surprised you didn't ask me about the sports angle.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm asking Jedediah.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: No help from me on that one, Doug.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: Well, I just think Jim Comey is trying to run out the clock when there's a lot to be answered. They've probably won't get answers.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: I think he just wants to DVR so that he can watch himself on TV. I mean, he's that kind of guy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I never do that.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Never. He wants to be the center of attention. He loves to be at the podium. And the audacity of this guy to think he can set the terms. If you subpoena him, oh, well, I'll do it, but I'll --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: This is the guy that's supposed to respect the law. See, that's what I'm saying --

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: I think he violated the law twice, both in July and then in October. Dana, are we going to come into a period of more investigations when my Democratic friends take over?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Every day you find out that there's going to be more. And I think that -- look, I think that they'll say that they have an obligation to do it, that there was a mandate from the people who voted for them that they wanted to check on this administration, how do you do that? Our founders set it up so that the legislative branch, check the executive branch, and there's a backstop of the judiciary.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: So simple question for all. Will we have an impeachment crisis?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Just targeting political opponents is what Democrats --

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: I think we may. Hillary Clinton is now slamming the press for not being tougher on President Donald Trump, her message next on The Five.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: This thanksgiving, we're thankful for Hillary Clinton for, of course, giving us more material to discuss. The failed presidential nominee is now criticizing the media over their coverage of President Trump. She tells The Guardian, quote, at some point the press has to get smart because that's basically how most voters get their information. If you're into the both sideism, so you know on the one hand this and on the other hand that, really there's no factual basis. There's no evidence. There's no record. Everybody lies, everybody gills the lily. It doesn't really matter. That's just opens a door to somebody like him. In that same interview, Hillary goes on to slam European leaders urging them to get control over the immigration crisis in order to deal with the rise of the right wing populist. I'm confused with her.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: You don't say.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: First of all, she won't go away. I've said this is harassment of American voter. But, Doug, what more does she wants the press to do? They're so hostile to the president. And look, here's the deal, I want the press to be hard on presidents. But it seems like they've just awoken from an eight year coma with the last administration, so what can the press do for this president?

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: Well, there's an answer, fortunately, to your question. What she wants, the press to slam President Trump and say she should run again, because as my former partner wrote in the Wall Street Journal this week, bottom line there is a strong desire among Hillary Clinton and her supporters to come back a divided field, maybe, just maybe, there'll be an opportunity for her to run.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: So, Dana, I guess this is a selfish act of her asking the press to essentially carry her water as they always do.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It is very hard for her to exit stage left or right. (INAUDIBLE)

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's a little clever.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: A little wordplay. Very little.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: I do. I worked for her.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I used to work for Mark Penn. Like, I respect that. I just think that there's just no way. The energy is not there. She has passed herself by date, politically --

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: I believe that, Dana. But she doesn't believe that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK, fine. But she's not going to get to some nomination. I mean, it would be just like be worse than ever. Can I comment on the thing that she said about immigration, though? So she was secretary of state when all of this stuff was happening with Angela Merkel, opening up the borders and saying we've got to bring in a million Syrian refugees because it's our moral obligation to do so. And she see like what actually happened to the country there. So, she's trying to let everybody know, this is a disaster waiting to happen. She looks at it because she says the problem is that led to the rise of right-wing extremists. The people who are in Germany say, well, not -- maybe -- OK -- but also it led to the rise in crime and a rise in all these other problems that have unfettered immigration allows. So she's trying to send a warning signal that that is what President Trump is trying to do as well. He's saying we've learned from Angela Merkel's mistakes. So, we agree with you, Hillary. And that's why, again, I go back to that I think something could happen on immigration because it kind of has to.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Greg, we've talked about this in the green room a little bit. Look, I'm for evaluating our side and talking about the extreme elements of it, but the problem is they present this lazy commentary as painting us all as the racists, as this racist, populist movement. What are your comments on that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, first, just to Hillary, I'm pretty certain that Fox has her under secret contract because she is delivering prepackaged segments on a weekly basis. We don't even have to do that much.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We just say verbatim -- between her and Avenatti, I think December is set for us.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: I think Avenatti is going to be unavoidably detained for a while.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. But it's going to be very hard for her. She's in a pickle. Because how could she call Trump a bigot if she just now trumpets his exact stance? She just embraced the stance that uncontrolled migration has a negative impact on your country. And it goes back to what we are talking about in the A-block, which is that the -- if you embrace a process, you can be portrayed as means or as bigoted, even though -- so you have to sacrifice your own P.R. for years. Whereas if you say, "Hey, you know, open borders, we love you. Come, come, come," you're Santa.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Real quick, Jedediah.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: She was friends with him for years.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: How does she continue to make these arguments about going to his wedding, partying with him?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: I think she legitimately feels robbed of this election. She thought it was hers. I don't think she has any self-awareness as to how bad she is at actually running.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: I know that.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: She really just doesn't get why she would lose, which is why she always pivots to Russia, because she can't fathom that people didn't come out and support her. And what's interesting is that she criticizes the media coverage of Trump. The media talked a lot about Trump, you know, and may be some argue that did help him get elected. It put him front and center, but most of that coverage was bad. Democrats couldn't stand him. Most in media couldn't stand him. A lot of Republicans did not want him to be the guy. They were looking at Marco Rubio. They were looking at Rand Paul. They were saying, "This guy isn't going to be safe. He doesn't know what he's doing." So to argue that the media wasn't smart of -- it's just -- it's a ridiculous -- and frankly --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Another thing she's blamed it on.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: That interview shows, though, why she's so terrible. It was hard to even follow her, what she was saying and where she was going. When you were saying it was confusing, this is why she's a terrible candidate. She doesn't take a message and hit it home, and she's the only person in the room that doesn't know that she shouldn't do that.

utterances.speaker: SCHOEN
utterances.sentences: She should go away.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: She has to look at herself. We've got to go. "The Fastest Seven" is coming up next, including the big Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade controversy that has the Twitter world in a tizzy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Tizzy?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Coming up.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Welcome back. Don't even ask what he's saying. It's time now for a Thanksgiving edition of "The Fastest Seven." First up --

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Black Friday craziness is in full swing. But if you're tired of circling the parking lot looking for a space at the mall, then listen up. There's now a robot that can save you and your car a spot. A new app called "My Park" deploys automatically place holders that will actually hold you a parking space. Once you arrive, the robot collapses so your car can drive over it. OK, this sounds like a terrible idea, Greg, but I have a feeling you're going to like it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, no.
